Award.AwardTitle: SG: Collaborative Research: A genomic analysis of the impact of genetic divergence, and chromosomal rearrangement on introgression in replicate Fundulus hybrid zones
Award.AbstractNarration:
Hybridization occurs when members of different species attempt to reproduce. While hybridization has traditionally been viewed as normally inconsequential to species integrity and the speciation process (hybrids were assumed to be inviable for some reason), there is growing evidence it may actually be beneficial and accelerate speciation under some circumstances. Understanding the origins of biodiversity requires more thorough knowledge of mechanisms that may alter the outcome of hybridization. One such mechanism is the rearrangement of chromosomes that may change the genomic structure of species in a way that limits the potential for hybridization. This project will study a model fish species, topminnows, in order to understand how divergence and chromosomal rearrangements may interact to determine the dynamics of naturally occurring hybrid zones. The research will also be used in development of high school curricula to teach evolutionary concepts and to provide research experiences for undergraduates.

Topminnows in the Fundulus notatus species complex have broadly overlapping ranges throughout much of the Mississippi River basin and northern Gulf of Mexico drainages. Earlier work with these species identified a number of replicate hybrid zones where the hybridizing species and populations differ in levels of divergence and, in some cases, chromosome number. The researchers will use modern genomic tools to quantify the amount of hybridization and patterns of introgression in eight replicate hybrid zones. Artificial breeding experiments in the laboratory will produce progeny that will facilitate the production of genetic maps of hybridizing populations. Genetic maps will elucidate spatial patterns of gene flow in replicate hybrid zones. Experimental hybrid zone trials will also examine mate choice dynamics and the viability of hybrid offspring.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Hybridization occurs when members of different species reproduce. While hybridization has traditionally been viewed as rare and inconsequential, biologists now recognize hybridization as common in nature with diverse, and in some cases, contradictory effects. Hybridization tends to be more common in groups of organisms that show greater levels of diversity, suggesting an important role in the evolutionary process. Hybridization can result in adaptive exchange of key genetic variation in some parts of the genome, while other parts of the genome remain isolated through a process called reinforcement. These contradictory processes can occur if the barriers to genetic exchange are porous, allowing exchange to occur in some regions of the genome even while other regions evolve to establish and reinforce species barriers. Both the processes of genetic exchange and reinforcement of reproductive isolation occur at the population level, and so may vary across the ranges of species, and may also be impacted by local environmental factors. Understanding the origins of biodiversity requires knowledge of factors that dictate the outcomes of hybridization at the population level. The roles of chromosomal rearrangements in determining the genomic architecture of species and the possible outcomes of hybridization are widely recognized and the subject of numerous recent and ongoing studies. Our research aimed to understand how divergence and chromosomal rearrangements may interact to determine the dynamics of hybridization and genetic exchange in topminnow contact zones.

Topminnows in the Fundulus notatus species complex have broadly overlapping ranges throughout much of the Mississippi River basin and coastal drainages throughout the central and southern United States. The two broadly distributed members of this species complex, the blackspotted topminnow and the blackstripe topminnow, differ in chromosome number, with varying numbers of chromosomes in the latter species having evolved by way of fusions via chromosome translocation. Earlier work with these species demonstrated that hybrid zone dynamics also varied substantially among drainages. In this study we developed genetic markers (single-nucleotide polymorphisms or SNPs) and used them to construct genetic linkage maps for populations with N = 20 and 22 chromosomes in blackstripe topminnows, and N = 24 chromosomes in blackspotted topminnows. Our genetic linkage maps complemented the known history of chromosome evolution in the species group.

Surveys of ten hybrid zones distributed in isolated drainages throughout the species ranges demonstrated the striking variation in outcomes ranging from extensive hybridization to a virtual absence of hybridization. Experimental hybrid zone trials in common garden settings controlled for environmental variability to assess its role in determining hybrid zone dynamics. Hybridization rates in these trials closely matched those observed in natural settings, suggesting that much of the variability in hybrid zone dynamics was genetically determined.

Data analysis of hybrid zones is ongoing with the goal remaining to determine the role of chromosome rearrangements as drivers of variability in genetic exchange across genomes within hybrid zones.
